section.title: XDI Push
section.para: Using XDI messaging and XDI link contracts, a publish/subscribe mechanism can be defined between two or more peers. It allows a peer called publishing peer (or short "publisher") to notify one or more other peers called subscribing peers (or short "subscribers") of changes in a graph for which the publishing peer is authoritative. It is not relevant what operation or peer caused the change.

A notification ("push") may either only reference the address of the target subgraph that has changed ("light push"), or it may contain the original XDI operation(s) that caused changes to the target subgraph ("content push").

section.title: Structure
section.para: A publish/subscribe relationship between a publishing authority and a subscribing authority is modeled as a link contract with the following characteristics:

listitem.para: The publisher is the authorizing authority.
The subscribers are the requesting authorities.
The link contract contains one ore more $push operations.
The link contract MAY contain one or more push target endpoint URIs.
The link contract MAY contain the content flag which specifies whether a subscriber wishes to use light pushes or content pushes.

section.para: A link contract fulfilling the above characteristics is also called a push contract. Following is the basic structure of a push contract. Labels in <--this-form--> represent template variables.

If the push contract does not contain at least one push target endpoint URI, the subscriber's XDI endpoint MUST be discovered using the XDI Discovery protocol. This XDI endpoint MUST then be used as the single push target endpoint URI of the push contract.
If the content flag is absent, the default value false (i.e. use light pushes) MUST be assumed.

Like all link contracts, push contracts are unidirectional and only apply to data in the authorizing authority's graph. In order to set up a bi- or multidirectional relationship, two or more push contracts can be created in which multiple authorities simultaneously fulfill the publisher and subscriber roles.

section.title: Creation
section.para: A push contract can be created in two ways, explicit and implicit.

section.title: Explicit creation
section.para: A push contract may be added to an XDI graph like any other structure, i.e. by executing a $set operation against a target graph.
In an XDI message that explicitly creates a push contract, the subscribing peer is the requester, and the publishing peer is the responder.
In order to add a push contract to an authorizing authority's graph, a subscribing authority requires either the $all, $set$push, or $get permissions [TODO: discuss and add explanation].

section.title: Implicit creation
section.para: A push contract may be added to an XDI graph implicitly by a responder while executing an XDI operation that cannot be immediately completed ("asynchronous messaging"). This occurs most commonly in the case of connection requests and connection invitations when user interaction is required (see XDI Connections spec).

Instead of sending a plain or full response message, the responder sends a deferred response message and creates a push contract. This implicit push contract is returned to the requester of the XDI operation. [TODO: more precise language and details].
In an XDI message that implicitly creates a push contract, the subscribing peer is the requester, and the publishing peer is the responder. [TODO: more precise language and details].

Once the original XDI operation is completed, the push contract is used to deliver a full response message to the original requester. The push contract may then be deleted. [TODO: more precise language and details].

section.title: Pushes
section.para: Once a push contract is in place, every change to a subgraph covered by the push contract results in a push being delivered from the publishing peer to the subscribing peer(s) using XDI messages.

XDI implementations MUST support light pushes and MAY support content pushes. Local policies of publishing peers MAY prohibit content pushes. If content pushes are not supported or prohibited, a subscriber MUST gracefully fall back to light pushes without raising an exception.

section.title: Light Pushes
section.para: A light push only references the address of the target subgraph that has changed. It uses the $push operation.

section.title: Content Pushes
section.para: A content push contains the original XDI operation(s) that caused changes to the target subgraph.

section.title: Authentication and Authorization
section.para: When a push contract is in place, it SHOULD exist both in the publishing peer's graph and in the subscribing peer's graph. The existence of the push contract in the subscribing peer's graph serves as authorization for incoming pushes from the publishing peer's graph.

appendix.title: Dollar Words
appendix.para: This appendix contains formal definitions of the XDI dollar words introduced by this specification.

listitem.para: $push: When used a link contract permission, establishes a push relationship between a publisher and one or more subscribers. When used as a message operation, represents a push being delivered from a pubisher to a subscriber.
$content: Used as a part of a push contract to specify whether to use light pushes or content pushes.
